description:
Actinomycetospora chlora is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Actinobacteria. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Actinomycetospora chlora is known to be a member of the actinomycete group, which are filamentous bacteria that play important roles in soil and aquatic environments.

The cells of Actinomycetospora chlora are typically rod-shaped and exhibit a characteristic greenish-yellow pigmentation, which is the basis for its species name "chlora" (meaning "green" in Greek). This pigmentation is likely due to the production of specific carotenoid compounds by the bacterium.

Actinomycetospora chlora has been isolated from various environmental samples, such as soil and freshwater habitats. It is known to be capable of degrading complex organic compounds and may play a role in nutrient cycling in its natural ecosystems.

The precise ecological functions and metabolic capabilities of Actinomycetospora chlora are still under investigation, as research on this relatively newly described species continues to expand our understanding of the diversity and roles of actinomycete bacteria in the environment.
